meanings.definition: The practice of buying enough shares in a company to threaten a takeover and then forcing the target company to buy the shares back at a premium to prevent the takeover.
meanings.sent1: Greenmail can happen when someone buys a lot of company shares to make them pay more money.
meanings.sent2: The company had to pay a lot of extra money to stop the takeover because of greenmail.
meanings.sent3: The shareholders played a tricky game of greenmail, making the company pay extra to keep control.
meanings.sent4: Greenmail is like a financial game of chess, where the threat of takeover leads to a costly move.
meanings.sent5: The concept of greenmail is like a financial trap, squeezing money out of companies in danger.

meanings.definition: To engage in the practice of greenmail.
meanings.sent1: Some investors greenmail companies to make a profit from the threat of takeover.
meanings.sent2: He decided to greenmail the company by buying enough shares to force them to buy them back.
meanings.sent3: The investor joked that he would greenmail the company if they didn't offer a better deal.
meanings.sent4: Greenmailing a company is like holding a financial sword over their heads.
meanings.sent5: She used the tactic of greenmail to pressure the company into meeting her demands.
